p: The synthesis of dihydroxerulin was first described by Siegel and Br√ºckner [ 132]. It began with stereoselective preparations of phosphorus ylide 1 and lactone aldehyde 2 and ended with a Wittig reaction between these entities. The process resulted in the formation of up to 30% of the trans Z isomer 3, along with up to 25% of a mixture of at least two stereoisomers. The same researchers synthesized xerulin via a convergent route and were able to get the pure form of the compound [ 132]. The total synthesis of xerulin by Negishi et al. [ 133] was accomplished from commercially available (E)-1-bromopropene, acetylene, and propynoic acid with 30% overall yield and >96% stereoselectivity.
